results.title: She’s Oscar-Nominated, but Hong Chau Hopes to Stay an Underdog
results.abstract: Up for best supporting actress for “The Whale,” she never dreamed of being a performer. But she has turned into “a force of nature,” says Brendan Fraser.

multimedia.caption: After struggling for roles, Hong Chau said the academy nod has put her in a weird place: “I still feel so new and I’m still learning, so I hope this doesn’t mean that people think I know what I’m doing.”
multimedia.copyright: Justin J Wee for The New York Times

results.title: Film Artists Reflect on the Movies that Left a Mark
results.abstract: For a retrospective series at the Berlin International Film Festival, directors and actors selected formative coming-of-age movies. Their choices show links between the cinematic past and present.

multimedia.caption: From left: Christina Ricci, Ashleigh Aston Moore, Gaby Hoffmann and Thora Birch in “Now and Then,” which is playing in a retrospective at the Berlin International Film Festival.
From left: Christina Ricci, Ashleigh Aston Moore, Gaby Hoffmann and Thora Birch in “Now and Then,” which is playing in a retrospective at the Berlin International Film Festival.
From left: Christina Ricci, Ashleigh Aston Moore, Gaby Hoffmann and Thora Birch in “Now and Then,” which is playing in a retrospective at the Berlin International Film Festival.

results.title: ‘Dancing the Twist in Bamako’ Review: Youth in Revolt
results.abstract: Robert Guédiguian’s jaunty new film places a young romance against the backdrop of post-colonial Mali in the early 1960s.

multimedia.caption: Alice Da Luz, left, as Lara and Stéphane Bak as Samba, who spends his days spreading the Marxist gospel to Mali’s peasants and landowners.
Alice Da Luz, left, as Lara and Stéphane Bak as Samba, who spends his days spreading the Marxist gospel to Mali’s peasants and landowners.
Alice Da Luz, left, as Lara and Stéphane Bak as Samba, who spends his days spreading the Marxist gospel to Mali’s peasants and landowners.

results.title: ‘We Have a Ghost’ Review: Me and My Boo
results.abstract: David Harbour stars as an apparition haunting a family’s home in this supernatural Netflix comedy.

multimedia.caption: In “We Have a Ghost,” a father (Anthony Mackie) and son (Jahi Winston) have opposing ideas on what to do about the ghost (David Harbour) in the house.
In “We Have a Ghost,” a father (Anthony Mackie) and son (Jahi Winston) have opposing ideas on what to do about the ghost (David Harbour) in the house.

results.title: What ‘Puss in Boots: The Last Wish’ Owes to Samurai and Sergio Leone
results.abstract: The DreamWorks sequel has garnered praise for its vibrant animation, darker story and fight sequences inspired by classic films.
des_facet: Puss in Boots: The Last Wish (Movie)
Good, the Bad and the Ugly, The (Movie)

multimedia.caption: The director of “Puss in Boots: The Last Wish” said that its vibrant animation style is an ode to the painterly look of Katsuhiro Otomo’s 1988 anime film “Akira,” one of the movie’s many sources of visual inspiration.

The director of “Puss in Boots: The Last Wish” said that its vibrant animation style is an ode to the painterly look of Katsuhiro Otomo’s 1988 anime film “Akira,” one of the movie’s many sources of visual inspiration.

results.title: Movie Honors the African Soldiers France Tried to Forget
results.abstract: The success of “Tirailleurs,” set in the mire and mayhem of World War I, has helped resurface the often neglected story of colonial soldiers forced to take up somebody else’s fight.

multimedia.caption: Omar Sy, top, and Alassane Diong in “Tirailleurs.” (The movie is called “Father and Soldier” in the United States.)
Omar Sy, top, and Alassane Diong in “Tirailleurs.” (The movie is called “Father and Soldier” in the United States.)
Omar Sy, top, and Alassane Diong in “Tirailleurs.” (The movie is called “Father and Soldier” in the United States.)

results.title: ‘Chocolat’: What France Knew
results.abstract: Newly restored, Claire Denis’s quasi-autobiographical “Chocolat,” a child’s-eye view of French colonialism, is austere yet vivid.

multimedia.caption: France (Cécile Ducasse), right, may be the nominal protagonist of the film, but its central character is Protée (Isaach de Bankolé).
France (Cécile Ducasse), right, may be the nominal protagonist of the film, but its central character is Protée (Isaach de Bankolé).
France (Cécile Ducasse), right, may be the nominal protagonist of the film, but its central character is Protée (Isaach de Bankolé).

results.title: ‘Naatu Naatu’ From ‘RRR’ Is a Worldwide Hit, but It Draws on Very Local Traditions
results.abstract: The composers and choreographer explain how they created the propulsive sequence that is nominated for best song.

multimedia.caption: Ram Charan, left, and N.T. Rama Rao Jr. performing “Naatu Naatu” in “RRR.”
Ram Charan, left, and N.T. Rama Rao Jr. performing “Naatu Naatu” in “RRR.”
Ram Charan, left, and N.T. Rama Rao Jr. performing “Naatu Naatu” in “RRR.”

results.title: For a Film About Korean Adoptees, a Group Effort
results.abstract: In “Return to Seoul,” a Parisian repeatedly visits her birth country. Neither the filmmaker nor the star were adopted, but they got help from friends.

multimedia.caption: From left, Larcher, Park, Badufle and Chou. The adoption experiences of Larcher and Badufle tracked so closely that the director considered changing the main character to a man.
multimedia.copyright: Benjamin Malapris for The New York Times

results.title: In ‘The Quiet Girl,’ an Irish Loneliness Rarely Seen Onscreen
results.abstract: The first Irish-language film to be nominated for an Oscar, directed by Colm Bairéad, tells a gentle story of cultural reticence.

multimedia.caption: In “The Quiet Girl,” Catherine Clinch plays Cáit, who is shuttled from her chaotic family home to live with relatives for the summer.
In “The Quiet Girl,” Catherine Clinch plays Cáit, who is shuttled from her chaotic family home to live with relatives for the summer.

results.title: ‘Bursting Proud’: Ireland Cheers Paul Mescal for Embracing Irish Language
results.abstract: On the red carpet for the British Academy Film Awards, the Oscar-nominated actor gave an interview in Ireland’s national language.
org_facet: British Academy of Film and Television

multimedia.caption: Paul Mescal at the British Academy Film Awards at the Royal Festival Hall in London. He spoke Irish during a red carpet interview, inspiring a conversation about use of the national language of Ireland.

Paul Mescal at the British Academy Film Awards at the Royal Festival Hall in London. He spoke Irish during a red carpet interview, inspiring a conversation about use of the national language of Ireland.

results.title: ‘God’s Time’ Review: Saving Her From Herself
results.abstract: Instead of making a thriller, the writer and director Daniel Antebi opts for a boho buddy comedy, with mixed results.

multimedia.caption: Liz Caribel Sierra and Dion Costelloe in “God’s Time.”
Liz Caribel Sierra and Dion Costelloe in “God’s Time.”
Liz Caribel Sierra and Dion Costelloe in “God’s Time.”

results.title: Christoph Waltz Has Some Thoughts
results.abstract: His title character in the new Amazon series “The Consultant” is a blend of pleasant and menacing, with some very specific ideas about running a business.

multimedia.caption: Waltz takes an analytical approach to acting, preferring not to talk too much about his “process,” or at least to have “an ironic distance” when disclosing it.
multimedia.copyright: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Juniper’ Review: Bad Grandma
results.abstract: Starring Charlotte Rampling, this New Zealand-set drama is a portrait of intergenerational bonding with a heavy dose of cynicism.

results.title: ‘Bruiser’ Review: Of Fathers and Fractures
results.abstract: A teenage boy is caught between the man who raised him and a new guiding figure in this affecting study of masculinity and coming of age.

results.title: ‘Linoleum’ Review: Rocket Plan
results.abstract: Jim Gaffigan plays a dual role as rival scientists in this mysterious yet surprisingly effective movie.

results.title: When the Movies Pictured A.I., They Imagined the Wrong Disaster
results.abstract: Instead of the chilling rationality of HAL in “2001: A Space Odyssey,” we get the messy awfulness of Microsoft’s Sydney. Call it the banality of sentience.

multimedia.caption: HAL 9000, the malevolent computer in Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey” (1968), is terrifying precisely because he is so ordinary.
HAL 9000, the malevolent computer in Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey” (1968), is terrifying precisely because he is so ordinary.

results.title: ‘A House Made of Splinters’ Review: Home Is Where the Hope Is
results.abstract: This film, an Oscar nominee this year for best documentary feature, has an aching sensitivity for the children in a Ukraine shelter.

results.abstract: A director crafts an elegiac tribute set during the dawn of the AIDS crisis in Brazil.

results.title: Laurie Metcalf to Return to Broadway in a Horror Story, ‘Grey House’
results.abstract: The play, directed by Joe Mantello and also starring Tatiana Maslany, had a well-reviewed debut in Chicago. It begins performances in April.

results.title: Sal Piro, ‘Rocky Horror Picture Show’ Superfan, Dies at 72
results.abstract: Like many others, he was riveted by the film and attended numerous midnight showings. Unlike many others, he made it the focus of his life.

multimedia.caption: Sal Piro, the president of the “Rocky Horror Picture Show” fan club, at a screening in Los Angeles in 2010 celebrating the movie’s 35th anniversary.

results.title: Daniels Win the Top DGA Award. Will They Take the Oscar, Too?
results.abstract: The duo triumphed for “Everything Everywhere All at Once.” The guild’s winner has won the best director Academy Award 17 of the last 20 times.

results.title: Stella Stevens, Hollywood Bombshell Who Yearned for More, Dies at 84
results.abstract: She starred alongside the likes of Elvis Presley and Jerry Lewis. But she wanted to direct and write, and she felt held back by industry sexism.

multimedia.caption: Stella Stevens with Jerry Lewis in a publicity photo for one of her best-known films, “The Nutty Professor” (1963).
